data.title: How to read Trump on Taiwan
data.meta_description: The former president wants Taipei to spend more on defense, and may seek concessions regarding chips.
data.text:
Donald Trumpâs declaration that Taiwan should pay the US for its defense has sparked jitters in Taipei, rattled chip stocks, and led to a fresh round of questions about his China policy.

A former Trump national security official, who acknowledged they fielded some concerns from Taiwanese officials about the comments, told Semafor Trumpâs remarks reflected his desire to get Taiwan to spend more than they currently do on defense given the growing threat from China to the island. That desire, former Trump officials have predicted, will be a key part of his Taiwan policy should he win a second term in the White House.

Former Trump national security adviser Robert OâBrien also said at a Bloomberg News event on the sidelines of the GOP convention in Milwaukee Thursday that Taiwan needs to âramp up their spending.â

âI think what President Trump is saying is... weâve got to have burden sharing,â he added.

When I set out to write about Trumpâs plans for China in a potential second term earlier this year, I asked people in his orbit about his plans for Taiwan. Across the board, former officials told me that he would push the Taiwanese to spend more than its current 2.5% GDP on defense, as he sees that as key to deterring a Chinese invasion of the island.

AD

Elbridge Colby, a conservative foreign policy thinker whose name has been floated for potential high-level Trump 2.0 positions, has called Taiwanâs current level of defense spending âwoefully inadequateâ given Chinaâs military buildup, and has suggested the island spend between 5% and 10% of its GDP on defense.

Trumpâs comments, made to Bloomberg Businessweek in June, can be read as part of a broader effort to encourage more spending. Taiwan does not receive US weapons for free; rather, it has paid billions for US military equipment, purchases that have benefited the US economy.

Trump has consistently refused to say whether the US would defend Taiwan under his administration, something former officials interpret as a policy of so-called âstrategic ambiguityâ and his desire to appear unpredictable to foreign adversaries and allies.

AD

That doesnât mean the US wouldnât come to Taiwanâs defense if it were under assault by China if Trump is in office, however.

When I asked Republican Sen. Lindsey Graham, a Trump ally in Congress, earlier this year whether Trump would ever echo Biden in vowing to defend Taiwan, Graham said he didnât need to: âI donât think he needs to say much. He just needs to be Trump.â

Graham added Trump views a Chinese invasion as the trigger for an âunraveling of the world,â and that heâs worried about the huge economic impact it would have, particularly on the global semiconductor chips supply. Indeed, Trump brought up semiconductors during the Bloomberg interview, accusing Taiwan of taking âalmost 100% of our chip industry.â

Lisa Curtis, who served on the National Security Council under the Trump administration, told me she interpreted Trumpâs comments as a signal he will âseek greater concessions from Taiwan regarding its high-end chip technology in exchange for US security support.â That could mean pushing Taiwanese chipmakers to invest more in the US (TSMC is already building three high-tech chip factories in Arizona with the help of billions in US grants).

âGiven that Trump often approaches foreign relations as a business venture and wants to show the American people he can drive hard bargains,â Curtis said. âThis is very typical Trump behavior and statements and I donât think anybody should be alarmed, and I donât think they should interpret this as meaning that Trump would be reluctant to come to Taiwanâs defense for example if it were attacked by China.â
